;‘I used to look at it as a wonderful Mansion.’ Novelist Charles Dickens (1812-1870) famously first saw Gads Hill Place in 1821, as a 9 year old boy. Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) ;Monk House,  Rodmell, Lewes, East Sussex, BN7 3HF;Loved for the 'shape and fertlity and wildness of the garden’, novelist Virgina Woolf (1882-1941) discovered Monk’s House in 1919. Anthony Trollope (1815-1882);The Grange, North Lane, South Harting, Petersfield, GU31 5NR;In 1880, novelist Anthony Trollope (1815-1882) moved The Grange, South Harting. where he would die in 1882. Both his pen, paperknife and letter scales are on display in the parish church;South East;-
Robert Louis Stevenson (1850-1894);Skerryvore, Alum Chine Road, Westbourne, Bournemouth, BH4;Destroyed in 1940 during the Second World War and now a vacant plot, novelist Robert Louis Stevenson (1850-1894) lived in the house called Skerryvore between 1885 and 1887. A memorial garden, dedicated to the writer, is situated on the plot.;South West;Memorial plaque
